channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. and U.K. Launch Heavy Strikes on Houthi Sites in Yemen
item.description: The airstrikes, meant to deter attacks on ships in the Red Sea, came one day after the United States struck at other Iran-backed militias in Iraq and Syria.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: A glow could be seen in the night sky behind buildings following strikes in Sana, Yemen, on Saturday.

item.title: Fear and Ambition Propel Xi’s Nuclear Acceleration
item.description: China’s leader built up a nuclear arsenal, steeling for a growing rivalry with the United States. Now China is exploring how to wield its newfound strength.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: A military parade in Beijing in 2019. As China’s nuclear options have grown, its military strategists are looking to nuclear weapons as not just a defensive shield, but as a potential sword.

item.title: Welcome to ‘Dalifornia,’ an Oasis for China’s Drifters and Dreamers
item.description: Young Chinese are flocking to the picturesque mountain town of Dali to escape the cutthroat competition and suffocating political environment of the country’s megacities.
item.dc:creator: Gilles Sabrié and Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Embracing one’s inner child, in Dali. Li Xiaoxue, center, moved there in August, after returning to China from Los Angeles. Ms. Li said Dali’s diversity and open-minded culture reminded her of California.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Test Iran’s Will to Escalate
item.description: American airstrikes hit Iran-linked targets in Syria and Iraq to retaliate for the recent killing of three U.S. soldiers in Jordan.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathering for a rally in Tehran last year.

item.title: After the Quake: One Turkish Family’s Struggle
item.description: In the year since earthquakes devastated southern Turkey, the Karapirli family has struggled to heal, find a home and cope with a bottomless sense of loss.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Safak Timur and Emin Ozmen
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times

item.title: Dozens Dead in Chilean Wildfires
item.description: The death toll is expected to rise as hundreds have been reported missing in the blazes near the cities of Viña del Mar and Valparaíso, an area home to more than a million people.
item.dc:creator: John Bartlett
item.media:description: Burned homes in Viña del Mar, Chile, on Saturday.

item.title: Germany Braces for Decades of Confrontation With Russia
item.description: Leaders are sounding alarms about growing threats, but Chancellor Olaf Scholz is wary of pushing the Kremlin, and his own ambivalent public, too far.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany speaking to the defense minister, Boris Pistorius, second from right, on Wednesday at the German Bundestag in Berlin.

item.title: Northern Ireland Names Sinn Fein’s Michelle O’Neill First Minister
item.description: The idea of a first minister who supports closer ties to the Republic of Ireland — let alone one from Sinn Fein, a party with historic ties to the Irish Republican Army — was once unthinkable. On Saturday, it became reality.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Michelle O’Neill of Sinn Fein at the Northern Ireland Assembly in Belfast on Saturday.

item.title: Senegal’s President, Macky Sall, Calls Off Election for His Replacement
item.description: The West African country had planned to hold an election in three weeks. But President Macky Sall canceled it indefinitely pending an inquiry into corruption allegations at the constitutional court.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Mady Camara
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: President Macky Sall of Senegal, center, attending an event last April in Dakar, the capital.

item.title: Mideast Crisis : U.S. and U.K. Launch Heavy Strikes on Houthi Sites in Yemen
item.description: The two countries said targets included weapons storage facilities, missile systems and launchers, air defense systems, and radars.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Newly recruited Houthi fighters in Sana, Yemen, on Thursday protesting American and British airstrikes.

item.title: UNRWA Funding: 8 Days of Turmoil for U.N.’s Top Agency in Gaza
item.description: The crisis that threatens the future of the main United Nations agency in Gaza, amid a humanitarian disaster, began at a routine meeting between diplomats in Tel Aviv.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: UNRWA aid in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip. The U.N. organization is the largest aid agency on the ground in Gaza, providing shelter to more than half the population.

item.title: Gaza Rescuers Go Missing on Mission to Save a Girl Trapped in a Car
item.description: The Palestine Red Crescent said the girl, named Hind, was in a car in northern Gaza with six of her relatives who were all killed by Israeli fire. She was the sole survivor.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Northern Gaza on Friday.

item.title: Ceferin’s UEFA Term Limits Fight Renews Debate on Presidential Power
item.description: A proposal that would weaken term limits at European soccer’s governing body has insiders and governance officials worried that sports’ power brokers are forgetting why the rules exist.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Aleksander Ceferin, center, at last year’s Champions League final in Istanbul, with the president of FIFA, Gianni Infantino, left, and the Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

item.title: Turkey’s Central Bank Chief Steps Down Amid Long Inflation Battle
item.description: The government swiftly replaced her and said the change did not reflect a policy shift for the country, where annual inflation is about 65 percent.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Hafize Gaye Erkan was Turkey’s fifth central bank chief in five years.

item.title: Pakistan’s Military Is Swaying Elections, Now More Than Ever
item.description: A political crackdown has been more visible than those in previous years, analysts say, making this week’s vote among the least credible in the country’s history.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathering for a meeting of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf party on a rooftop at the home of a supporter in Lahore, last week. Members of the party have faced intimidation, censorship and arrest.

item.title: Hage Geingob, Namibia’s President, Is Dead at 82
item.description: He was the country’s first prime minister after it gained independence from South Africa in 1990.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Hage Geingob of Namibia speaking at the 74th session of the United Nations General Assembly in 2019.

item.title: House GOP Plans Vote on Israel Aid as Senate Tries to Close Ukraine Deal
item.description: The move comes as the Senate is racing to finalize and vote on a bill that would also include new border policies and funding for the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson has said that the Senate package would be dead on arrival in the House.

item.title: Exploring the Backyard
item.description: While a grand trip might offer novelty and excitement, there’s adventure to be found in territories much closer to home.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: A Public Inquiry Into Foreign Election Meddling Comes Up Against Secrecy
item.description: The first week of hearings by a special commission focused on the question of how top-secret intelligence can be made public.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Justice Marie-Josée Hogue was given a tight schedule for her inquiry into election meddling.

item.title: Bank of America Pledged to Stop Financing Coal. Now It’s Backtracking.
item.description: The changes come as Republican lawmakers step up efforts to punish businesses that consider climate change and the environment in their operations.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: Demonstrators at a Bank of America branch last year calling on banks to stop financing fossil-fuel projects.

item.title: Syria and Iraq Say U.S. Strikes Killed Civilians
item.description: tk
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Douglas C. Brunelle/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The U.S. military strikes that targeted sites in Syria and Iraq were largely conducted by two American B-1B bombers.

item.title: In Australia and New Zealand, Barefoot Is a Way of Life
item.description: A celebration of (at least occasional) shoelessness.
item.media:description: A barefoot man at a bakery in Byron Bay, Australia, last year.

item.title: Lights! Camera! Modi! It’s a One-Man Show on Indian Television.
item.description: The grand opening of a temple in Ayodhya was both a religious ritual and a made-for-TV spectacle for a broadcast media co-opted by Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Reporters inside Ram Temple in Ayodhya, India, after the opening ceremony last month.

item.title: Israel Signals Its Military Will Move Into Rafah, in Southern Gaza
item.description: A U.N. official described Rafah, a refuge for hundreds of thousands of displaced people, as a “pressure cooker of despair.” It is one of the last cities in southern Gaza that Israeli ground forces have not reached.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Nick Cumming-Bruce and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Palestinians amid what’s left of destroyed buildings after an Israeli strike in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: U.S. Hits Back at Iran With Sanctions, Criminal Charges and Airstrikes
item.description: The Biden administration used sanctions and criminal charges to punish the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, Iran’s premier military force.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: West Asia News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photograph released by Iranian state news in August shows members of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps.

item.title: What Withholding Funds to UNRWA Means for Gaza
item.description: After 12 employees of the U.N. agency were accused of participating in the Oct. 7 attack against Israel, some donor countries have suspended funding. But more than a million people in Gaza depend on the agency for aid.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flour is distributed by UNRWA in Khan Younis, the Gaza Strip, in November. Some employees of the U.N. agency have since been accused of participating in the Oct.7 terrorist attack on Israel.

item.title: U.S. Conducts Retaliatory Strikes Against Iranian Proxies as War Deepens
item.description: The strikes, in response to a drone attack that killed three U.S. soldiers in Jordan this week, were a sharp escalation of hostilities in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden approved the strikes earlier in the week, though he and his top aides have been reluctant to take steps that could draw the United States into a broad conflict.

item.title: What to Know About the Return of Power-Sharing in Northern Ireland
item.description: For the first time, a Sinn Fein politician will serve as first minister.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Sinn Fein Vice President Michelle O’Neill addressing the news media on the imminent return of the Northern Ireland government at Stormont this week.

item.title: U.S. Leading Soft Landing for Global Economy
item.description: Economies all over the world are lowering inflation while avoiding serious recession — but growth in the United States stands out.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek, Ana Swanson, Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Americans have only slowly spent down the savings they amassed during the early pandemic years, so the money has continued to trickle through the economy like a slow-release booster shot.

item.title: U.N. Court to Rule on Whether Ukraine Committed Genocide
item.description: The highest court of the United Nations will render a verdict on a claim that has been used by Russia to justify its invasion.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Joan E. Donoghue, left, the president of the International Court of Justice, reading the ruling in a case brought to the court by Ukraine.

item.title: How Shrinking Populations Fuel Divisive Politics
item.description: A look into the future shows the importance of immigration.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub and Lauren Leatherby
item.media:credit: Source: U.N. World Population Prospects 2022 | Working-age people are those between the ages of 15 and 64, an age group commonly used by demographers. | The New York Times

item.title: U.N. Climate Chief Warns Countries Against ‘Hiding Behind Loopholes’
item.description: Simon Stiell used a speech in Azerbaijan to set expectations for global climate negotiations there this year.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Simon Stiell, head of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, at last year’s summit in Dubai.

item.title: How Closely Does Iran Control Its Proxy Forces? It Depends.
item.description: Tehran provides arms and support to an array of militant groups across the Mideast, but it does not call all the shots, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-government Iranians gathering near a banner that warns Iran’s enemies — in Farsi and in Hebrew — to “Prepare your coffins,” this month in Tehran.

item.title: January Transfer Window Totals: Where Have All the Deals Gone?
item.description: A quiet January window may not be a bubble bursting, but rather an awareness that the player-acquisition business has changed.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Nick Potts/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: January 2024: When Ivan Toney staying put qualifies as big news.

item.title: Pigeon Was Cleared of Being a Chinese Spy, but Served 8 Months Anyway
item.description: Birds, be careful: Loitering at an Indian port with a microchip on your leg can make people nervous and get you locked up.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.category: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
item.media:credit: Anshuman Poyrekar/Hindustan Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The pigeon was released on Tuesday from the veterinary hospital that had held it since it was found wandering in a port with Chinese writing on its wings.

item.title: Over 800 Officials in U.S. and Europe Sign Letter Protesting Israel Policies
item.description: The document was signed by government employees in 12 nations and E.U. institutions. Signers say their leaders’ policies could be contributing to war crimes in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Destruction in the Al Maghazi refugee camp in Gaza on Thursday. The letter is the first instance of officials in allied nations across the Atlantic coming together to openly criticize their governments over the war.

item.title: Fire From Explosion of Gas-Laden Vehicle Kills at Least 3 in Nairobi
item.description: More than 270 others were injured in the late-night blaze that burned many homes and a warehouse.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Malaysia Halves Sentence of Najib Razak, Fallen Ex-Prime Minister
item.description: His release has been set for August 2028 and his fine reduced to a quarter of its original amount, a move that has drawn criticism from observers and citizens.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Tashny Sukumaran
item.media:description: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak being escorted by prison officers after court proceedings in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, last month.

item.title: In Russia, a Cat Thrown From a Train Offers a Safe Space to Vent
item.description: The death of a pet during a train journey has given Russians a safe space to speak out and connect, and allowed the Kremlin to shift attention from wartime gloom.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev

item.title: He Cracked Down on Gangs and Rights. Now He’s Set to Win a Landslide.
item.description: The millennial president, Nayib Bukele, and his party are likely to win resoundingly in elections Sunday. His running mate says they are “replacing” democracy.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Fred Ramos
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Fred Ramos for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nayib Bukele’s face adorns an apartment building in the Zacamil neighborhood of San Salvador. The Barrio 18 street gang controlled the neighborhood for decades until its members were arrested under Mr. Bukele’s crackdown.

item.title: Cleaning Latrines by Hand: ‘How Could Any Human Do That?’
item.description: Bezwada Wilson, born into a caste tasked with manually removing dried human waste, has spent 40 years trying to eradicate the practice and retrain workers.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bezwada Wilson leads one of the largest organizations fighting against caste discrimination in India.

item.title: In the West Bank, Palestinians Struggle to Adjust to a New Reality
item.description: The volatile mix of violence, tensions and Israeli restrictions has had a stultifying effect on the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Yara Bayoumy and Rami Nazzal
item.media:description: A Palestinian man walks near the Qalandiya checkpoint in the West Bank in November. Some Palestinians say the Israelis have made it more difficult to cross into Jerusalem from the West Bank.

item.title: China Meets the U.S. to Discuss Fentanyl, But the Détente Has Limits
item.description: Negotiations have resumed on restricting the flow of fentanyl into the United States. But Beijing may prove less cooperative on Iran and North Korea.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Olivia Wang
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Wang Yi of China and Jake Sullivan, the U.S. national security adviser, in Bangkok last week. Mr. Sullivan urged China to restrain North Korea and Iran.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: The E.U. reached a Ukraine aid deal.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman transporting humanitarian aid last month to her home in the town of Chasiv Yar, on the frontline in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region.

item.title: Who Are the Israelis Under U.S. Sanctions Over West Bank Violence?
item.description: The White House announced financial penalties on the men, ranging in age from 21 to 32, over escalating violence against Palestinian civilians.
item.dc:creator: Johnatan Reiss, Gaya Gupta and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Working to repair cars damaged, like the building alongside them, in a settler rampage in the West Bank village of Huwara last February.

item.title: Friday Briefing: The E.U.’s Ukraine Aid Deal
item.description: Also, U.S. sanctions on Israeli settlers and battles over bullfighting.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Ukraine is facing one of is most difficult moments since Russia’s invasion.

item.title: Plan to Resurface a Pyramid in Granite Draws Heated Debate
item.description: A project to restore granite blocks that once covered a greater portion of the Pyramid of Menkaure in Giza has been criticized by some preservationists.
item.dc:creator: Julia Halperin
item.media:description: The Pyramid of Menkaure was once clad partly in granite blocks, visible in the lower portion. A plan to restore more of them is generating debate.

item.title: French Farmers Are Urged by Unions to End Roadblocks
item.description: The call from two main farmers’ unions came after President Emmanuel Macron’s government announced new financial aid and plans to loosen regulations to end the nationwide protests.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: French farmers standing next to their tractors as they block the road during a demonstration at the French-German border.

item.title: Iran Tries to Avoid War With U.S. After Stoking Mideast Conflicts
item.description: After Iran-aligned militants killed three American soldiers, Iran’s leaders sensed a line was crossed, and are sending more conciliatory signals while awaiting President Biden’s promised response.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Hossein Salami, the commander in chief of the Revolutionary Guards Corps, during the funeral ceremony of guard members who were killed in an airstrike in Syria last month.

item.title: Austin Says Iran Trains and Funds Militias Targeting U.S. Troops
item.description: President Biden has promised to respond to attacks that killed three American service members at a base in Jordan.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III’s remarks came as the United States and the Iran-backed Houthis engaged in a flurry of back-and-forth strikes.

item.title: EU Ukraine Aid Deal Is a Pawn in Orban’s Longer Populist Game
item.description: His real aim is to lead a populist and nativist rebellion against Europe’s liberal elite, though that campaign is showing signs of faltering.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, second from right, yielded to pressure from other European leaders on Thursday and agreed to funding for Ukraine.

item.title: Grateful for E.U. Aid, Ukraine Now Waits for the United States
item.description: The E.U. package of about $54 billion will be spent on nonmilitary expenses, like pensions, payments to displaced people and paying teachers and doctors.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman transporting humanitarian aid last month to her home in the town of Chasiv Yar, on the frontline in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region.

item.title: Old-Time Modernity: Cycladic Art at the Met
item.description: A major collection of early Greek figures and vessels takes up long-term residence in New York — a transformative event.
item.dc:creator: Roberta Smith
item.category: The Leonard N. Stern Collection of Cycladic Art on Loan from the Hellenic Republic (Exhibit)

item.title: Paris Police Investigating $1.6 Million Wine Theft From Famed Restaurant
item.description: More than 80 bottles of rare wine were discovered to be missing from the cellar of a 400-year-old restaurant during a routine inventory check.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Wine worth $1.6 million was stolen from La Tour d’Argent.

item.title: Biden Imposes Sanctions on Israelis Over West Bank Violence
item.description: The order served as both a sharp-edged diplomatic notice to Israel and a message to Arab Americans, a key part of the political coalition the president needs to be re-elected.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden speaking in Warren, Mich., to members of the United Auto Workers Union, which recently endorsed him. Michigan is vital to Mr. Biden’s campaign for a second term.

item.title: Iran Slows Production of Enriched Uranium, U.N. Official Says
item.description: The move suggests that Tehran may be trying to ease tensions with the United States.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Iran has resumed production of enriched uranium and now has a stockpile of fuel far larger than the limits set in a 2015 accord.

item.title: Jack Jennings, P.O.W. Who Helped Build Burma Railway, Dies at 104
item.description: He was captured by the Japanese in Singapore and was one of thousands of prisoners whose hardships were the basis for the film “The Bridge on the River Kwai.”
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: The Bridge on the River Kwai (Movie)
item.media:description: Jack Jennings was drafted into the British Army and sent to Singapore to fight the Japanese. Weeks later, Britain surrendered the island and Mr. Jennings was taken prisoner.

item.title: The Dogs That Live Longest, by a Nose
item.description: Small dogs with prominent noses live longer than bigger, flat-faced canines, a new study suggests.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; Photographs by Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times

item.title: Monkey Who Escaped in Scotland is Captured
item.description: A Japanese macaque escaped from a wildlife park on Sunday. After five days of “living his best life,” he was back home on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
